headline.main: Diabetes Rises; Doctors Foresee A Harsh Impact

docs.abstract: Incidence of Type 2 diabetes increases markedly in US from 1990 to 1998, rising 76 percent among people in their 30's, and researchers predict that it will continue to snowball and take a harsh toll in disability, death and medical expenses in decades to come; doctors attribute much of the rise to obesity, for which they blame tendency of Americans to park themselves in front of television and computer screens, exercising too little and eating too much; cost of diabetes is now estimated at $98 billion a year; map shows rise of diabetes state by state (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The incidence of diabetes increased markedly in the United States from 1990 to 1998, including a 76 percent rise in cases among people in their 30's, researchers are reporting today, and they warn that the disease will take a harsh toll in disability, death and medical expenses in decades to come. Doctors attribute much of the rise to obesity, which is also increasing steadily, with more than half of Americans now overweight. Most of the patients have Type 2 diabetes, commonly called adult onset diabetes, which accounts for 90 percent to 95 percent of the cases of the disease and can be brought on by inactivity and weight gain. Type 1 diabetes, which accounts for most of the remaining 5 percent to 10 percent of cases, is caused by a malfunction of the immune system and is not linked to obesity.
